main event: A bright light was observed briefly moving northward at an estimated speed of 60 to 80 mph at an altitude of 1000 to 2000 feet in Dayton, Ohio, on November 10, 1953. The object was too bright and possibly reflecting light, and there was insufficient data to identify it.
interesting points: The observer witnessed a bright light moving at a speed of 60 to 80 mph at an altitude of 1000 to 2000 feet, but there was insufficient data to determine its identity.

A separate event on November 14, 1950, involved the observation and photography of an anomalous globe of light in Elyria, Ohio, which was not visible to the naked eye, leading to speculation about its nature.
Research suggested that the anomalous object may have been a result of emulsion fluid droplets or air bubbles in careless film development, raising doubts about the authenticity of the photographs.
It was hypothesized that the anomalous globe of light may have been under remote control, based on its characteristics and behavior.

A questionnaire was included in the report, requesting details about the observation, such as the location, time, duration, and characteristics of the object, as well as the witness's personal information and educational background.
photographs: no the report does not include photographs
